I don't think English typically makes the distinction between masculine/feminine for blonde. From the Oxford dictionary; gt;The alternative spellings blonde and blond correspond to the feminine and masculine forms in French, but in English the distinction is not always made, as English does not have such distinctions of grammatical gender. Thus, blond woman or blonde woman, blond man or blonde man are all used. The word is more commonly used of women, though, and in the noun the spelling is typically blonde. In American usage the usual spelling is blond for both adjective and noun

Are you over filling your waffle iron perhaps? The first time I used it, I clearly added too much batter and it spilled out of the sides as it expanded. Since I reduced the amount I use, there's been very little cleaning needed - unless your iron isn't nonstick, then it's a big yikes.

It has very little taste (unless you add a little garlic powder/dried onion) and it isn't eggy. I think it's like a much lighter fathead. They're really really good! Little tip - add a little grated cheddar on the top of your waffle as it cooks if you're planning on making a sandwich and have that as the outside of your "bread". It gives it that authentic crunchy bite.
Sounds like you're cooking it for too long or too high.
Quick wipe with a wet cloth when it's still hot is all you need!

Isn't that just a school uniform?

I disagree completely. School uniforms are actually pretty beneficial in helping students feel less alienated. Poorer students or those that don't care about dressing "cool" don't need to worry about being victimised by their peers. Also, this kid had the new trousers but they were "too itchy", so it's not like they couldn't afford them. Sometimes in life you have to do stuff you don't really want to - wearing a proper school uniform can help kids prepare for that.
